results.title: A Scrap of paper and a piece of string
results.creator_credit: John Korty and Exploring for the National Broadcasting Company
results.brief_description: An animated film about a scrap of paper which boasts of being more useful than a piece of string. However, after turning into a paper boat and getting blown over in the water, the paper finds the string of use after all. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.

results.title: A Scaley situation
results.creator_credit: James Mann, Education Department of Victoria for Zoo Education Services and Mark Laughlin
results.brief_description: Linda Roach interviews Chris Banks, Keeper in Charge and Jon Birkett from the Melbourne Zoo who outline the physical characteristics of various reptiles. Illustrates first aid for venomous reptile bites. Warning: Some scenes depict zoo animals feeding. Parents and teachers are advised that some of these scenes may upset young children.

results.title: A Say in your community with the Australian Assistance Plan
results.brief_description: Made for he Social Welfare Commission and Department of Social welfare, the film explains the concept and illustrates the benefits available to community groups throughout Australia under the Australian Assistance Plan, a revolutionary concept in the identification of community need areas.

results.title: A Saucer of water for the birds
results.brief_description: The unusual technique of sand animation is used to tell the story of a woman and her granddaughter. It starts with them sitting at the kitchen table playing cards. As the cards are shuffled and cut, the film cuts between pre-war Poland, Europe in the Holocaust, the woman’s childhood and the present. The old woman’s homeland is evoked as a world the child strives to create from anecdotes. The woman’s present is shown as one etched with darkness of her family’s experience of the Holocaust.

results.title: A Saucer of water for the birds
results.brief_description: An animated short. A woman and her grandmother sit together playing cards. As they are shuffled and dealt, the film cuts between pre-war Poland, Europe during the Holocaust, the woman’s childhood, and the present. A meditation on the relationship between public history and personal memory, as it is played out in the dynamics of the family.

A meditation on the relationship between public history and personal memory, as it is played out in the dynamics of the family.

results.title: A Safety net
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Battle for the planet”.
The presenter of this program, Professor Eddie Ayensu of Ghana, is a leading African commentator on development issues. His concern in this program is what he sees as the damage which food aid does to African economics. To him, this aid creates a psychological dependence in the minds of farmers and acts as a disincentive to their own production. Ayensu says food aid was originally intended to provide African countries with room to manoeuvre, but now unwanted foods (such as sugar) is virtually being dumped. He looks at the staple foods in Africa such as Cassava, fish and fruit and makes the point that if Western aid went into improving productivity in these industries, African food production would be much more efficient and better able to feed the population.

results.title: A Run for your money
results.creator_credit: Charles Cahill and Charles Cahill and Associates
results.brief_description: A Japanese uses about one quarter of the energy used by an American. When fuel economy counts, it is important to watch driving habits, it is also important to use smaller cars, not carry heavy things unless necessary, not over utilise air conditioning and make sure that the cars used receive regular maintenance.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Charles Cahill and Charles Cahill and Associates

results.title: A Rosewood daydream
results.brief_description: This is the name of a Toronto folk group - two young men, a blue-eyed woman, and a guitar. They sing outdoors, indoors, wherever there’s a friendly audience. Most of the “with it” listeners in this film are the old folks in a home for the aged in St. John’s, Newfoundland. To them the group sings old songs of the sea, and a popular tune, Louis Collins, by Mississippi John Hurt.

results.title: A roof over your head; Detective work in the woods
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Dandelion = Pusteblume”.
Two episodes of the successful children’s series Pusteblume. “A roof over your head” - People live in houses in order to protect themselves from the wind, rain, heat or cold. Peter Lustig experiences what can happen without a roof over one’s head. In addition, he shows us how people build new houses and how some animals build themselves a hideaway. “Tracks in the wood” - Peter Lustig finds lots of tracks made in the wood by animals who live there. Naturally, he also hears lots of different noises made by animals when they forage for food or creep through the undergrowth. People go into the woods too of course, to collect mushrooms or just to go for a walk. The forest ranger is really cross with those who rubbish the woods and damage the natural environment.

results.title: A Rock climb
results.creator_credit: Boy Scouts of America. Visual Education Service
results.brief_description: The film describes the activities of a rock-climbing Explorer Unit from Phoenix, Arizona - the Kachinas. First their equipment and techniques are demonstrated and then the camera records the actual climb of a sheer peak in the Arizona Desert, a peak never before climbed by man.
